Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
WGBH will produce a third season of Design Squad, PBS reality competition series-with an accompanying outreach campaign and Web site (pbskidsgo.org/designsquad)-designed to inspire a new generation of engineers. Through the show, teenagers learn to think smart, build fast, and contend with a wild array of engineering challenges-all for real-life clients. Targeted to 9- to 12-year-olds, and fun for people of all ages, this fast-paced TV series is the fuel behind a national, multimedia initiative designed to attract kids to engineering.

The plan is to continue to build on the excitement and momentum have created during Seasons I and II, while also creating many innovations in project deliverables. More specifically, the four overarching goals are to (1) expand the project's reach into the middle school classroom with materials that will enable teachers to integrate engineering into their curriculum; (2) broaden participation with the TV show by casting contestants nationwide and producing three challenges at locations around the country (the Nevada desert, New Orleans, and Alaska); (3) create the first online community where kids can share their real-world engineering projects and provide a richer video viewing experience with embedded "pop-up" commentary; and (4) support existing partnerships especially with engineering professional societies, while forming new ones.

Design Squad and its "Middle School Classroom" initiative will have maximum impact: (1) addressing a critical need in engineering education and children?s television; (2) increasing students, knowledge of engineering and the design process; and (3) showcasing engineering as creative, rewarding, and socially relevant, especially to girls and minorities.

Formative and summative will inform both future seasons of Design Squad and the informal and formal science education community at large, which is lacking research on how teachers can integrate engineering into the middle school science curriculum.

This project is co-funded by Directorate for Education and Human Resources and the Directorate for Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design Squad Season III Project Outcomes Report

 

During Season III, Design Squad continued to bring an innovative combination of engineering content and reality show competition to ‘tween viewers, while showcasing design challenges and illustrating what it means to be an engineer. NSF’s support for Season III was crucial in bringing the excitement of science and technology to kids, educators, and engineers. More specifically, Design Squad achieved the following project goals: 1) expanding our reach into the middle school classroom; 2) broadening participation with the TV show; 3) creating a more robust Web site; and 4) supporting existing partnerships, while forming new ones.

 

1)    Expanding our reach into the middle school classroom 

With the Design Squad “Middle School Classroom” initiative, we leveraged Design Squad’s broadcast resources, in tandem with the project’s Web site and other outreach resources, to enable teachers to integrate engineering into their classrooms. The Teacher’s Guide we created provided a breadth of engineering and design activities aligned with schools’ science curricula. Concord Evaluation Group performed an experiment (randomized block design) to explore the extent of learning and changes in attitudes of students who used the Middle School Classroom initiative. They reported that the resources helped students in a significant way learn key science concepts and develop skills that are essential to performing engineering challenges. Moreover, they helped students develop a deeper and more positive understanding of engineering. Teachers surveyed agreed that Design Squad made their students more excited about engineering as a career choice and provided an opportunity for students to educate one another about the design process. They also reported that the Design Squad challenges strengthened their students’ ability to cite examples of what an engineer does and helped them expand their definition of what engineers do.

 

2)    Broadening participation with the TV show

To broaden participation with the TV show, we moved beyond Boston by selecting contestants via a nationwide search—cast members hailed from Miami, Massachusetts, Texas, Pennsylvania, and North Carolina. We also produced three challenges at the following locations: New Orleans, Jamaica, and an island off the North Shore of Massachusetts—startlingly different environments that served as a dramatic context for engineering. The corresponding design challenges—a rescue vehicle for the New Orleans fire department, dry-land dog mushing, and a sailboat—were the highlight of Season III’s ten half-hour episodes. Season III continued to reach its target audiences—compared to other PBS Kids programming, Design Squad had the highest percentages of teens, African Americans, low-income households, and families who have heads of household with lower education rates. Additionally, Design Squad continued to collect awards. The iParenting Media Awards honored Design Squad with a Best New Product of 2009 Award; Design Squad’s Web site was a Japan Prize Finalist for 2009; and Design Squad’s editing team was nominated for a Daytime Emmy.
